Hi all,

Having read the recent CPPN papers from Ken's group it seems to me=
 
that this is potentially a large leap forward for neuro-evolution. So 
fo=
r me an obvious question now would be - are there any well defined 
and wel=
l known problem domains in the realm of machine learning that 
are currentl=
y unsolved (or not satisfactorily solved) that CPPN would 
be ideally suite=
d to? Sort of low hanging fruit type problems if you 
like that would furth=
er demonstrate the effectiveness of CPPN's.

I'll be scanning the internet =
for ideas on this but no doubt some of 
you have already discussed this and=
/or have some ideas on the matter. 
Having just read Jason Gauci's + Ken's =
paper regarding the 
distinguishing of large and small objects in a visual =
field it seems 
to me that CPPNs are ideally suited to such visual tasks an=
d that 
maybe there are some visual problem domains that would be 
appropri=
ate. E.g. There's that old chestnut of detecting cancer cells 
in slide cro=
ss sections - so improving accuracy on a well known 
problem domain.

Colin=
.
